description: An excellent introduction to the world of business. Accounting is sometimes referred to as the language of business because its very purpose is to provide meaningful information to managers, investors, creditors, and government agencies with interest in a business.
learningOutcomes: Apply the Marriott Values to class and peer interactions to improve learning and the experience in ACC 200 for yourself and others
Interpret and analyze the primary financial statements, including the balance sheet, income statement, statement of cash flows, and statement of equity

Use internal accounting tools such as product costing, cost-profit-volume analysis, non-routine decision, and the balanced scorecard analyses to understand how to make better business management decisions
Manage workload in a self-paced learning environment by meeting regular deadlines
requiredMaterials: Required course packet to purchase at the bookstore
Basic calculator for exams (any calculator except phone)
Financial calculator HP 10bII+ recommended for future business classes

preClassWork.reviewQuiz: Weekly review quiz with unlimited attempts before deadline. Highest score kept. One dropped.
preClassWork.lessonContent: Videos with self-check questions and interactive activities. Videos can be played at 1X-1.75X speed.
preClassWork.applications: Real-world accounting assignments. Two dropped in final grade calculation.
preClassWork.moduleQuiz: Graded quiz with 59 minute limit, typically takes 15-20 minutes. Open-book. One attempt. Two dropped.

courseStructure.classTime: In-person class meetings to practice, answer questions, and learn new concepts. Attendance required. Material covered will be on exams.
courseStructure.syllabusQuiz: First week assessment of syllabus comprehension. Unlimited attempts. Cannot be dropped.

exams.location: BYU Testing Center (in-person required, includes Salt Lake Center)
exams.secondChanceExam: Optional retake with maximum score capped at 75%. Different exam version.

grading.note: No make-up or grade improvement projects. Scale subject to adjustment.

includes: Being courteous, respectful, and helpful to peers, TAs, and faculty
Asking questions and offering assistance where needed
Checking syllabus and Canvas before asking TAs or instructor
Taking responsibility for learning and participating actively in class

keysToSuccess: Math proficiency not required - just basic addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division
Focus on organizing and analyzing information
Master business language and terminology for proper communication
High self-discipline required to not fall behind
Set up personal study schedule with dedicated times for coursework
Allocate 2-3 hours outside of class for every hour spent in class
